This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
YOUR EXPERIENCE OF EARLY SCHOOL ACTIVITY

43. Did you have much formal grammar (paralinguistic words, picking out subject, predicate, object, etc.)? Yes, a lot.

44. Describe any activities designed to improve the mastery of spoken and written English. Every pupil in the class was encouraged to improve his spoken English by writing exercises in which he had to use nouns, verbs, adjectives, etc., in context. The emphasis was on improving the spoken English of the pupils.

45. Were pupils very often asked to write compositions, and how important a part did this activity play in school? We found a lot of composition.

46. Did any of the teachers encourage pupils to write poetry? No.

47. Did pupils do much speaking before the rest of the school, such as telling stories, giving talks, holding debates, etc.? Yes, quite a lot.

48. Was any language besides English taught in any of the public school grades? Yes, Latin.

What proportion of the children, if any, could not speak English when they started school? We don't know.

Were they given special instruction to help them learn English, or were they just left alone to "pick it up" from the other children? They were all helped.
